Human: Fall Flat is a quirky, physics-based puzzle platformer that delivers endless fun through its charmingly awkward characters and challenging puzzles. Players control Bob, a wobbly, customizable humanoid character, as they navigate a series of open-ended levels filled with puzzles that require creativity, cooperation, and a good sense of humor. The game’s mechanics revolve around manipulating objects and the environment in unique ways, often leading to hilarious and unpredictable outcomes.

The physics-driven gameplay can be both amusing and frustrating, as Bob's flailing arms and unpredictable movements create comedic moments but also add challenge to tasks. It’s a game best enjoyed with friends, as the cooperative multiplayer mode amplifies the chaos and laughter.

Visually, Human: Fall Flat offers a simplistic, low-poly art style that complements its light-hearted tone. Though it can feel repetitive at times, the game's charm and ability to make even simple tasks entertaining keeps players engaged. It's a great pick for casual gamers looking for a fun and occasionally absurd experience, especially when shared with others.

A wacky, wobbly physics based game that is fun either solo or with friends! I had originally played this game about 7 years ago on Nintendo Switch and to be honest, I didn't appreciate the game very much. At least, nowhere near as much as I should have. I didn't make that mistake the second time around on Steam Deck OLED.

This game is a blast, and it is incredibly fun figuring out different ways to get through each area and solve the various puzzles that are presented throughout the campaign. If the main levels weren't enough, you also have access to "Extra Dreams" which are large levels that are designed around a particular theme. Every single one of them are fun to play and most of them are drastically different in comparison to each other. If that also wasn't enough, there are thousands of Steam Workshop levels and character skins to choose from that will extend your gameplay time immensely. I haven't even finished all of the Extra Dreams yet.

The soundtrack in this game is hard to describe, but it exactly what I would think a game's music in a game named Human Fall Flat would be. There are a few clever songs that evoke a range of emotions though they mostly only play during the beginning of a level, or when you progress far enough to reach a key point in the level. I also enjoy the random quiet ambiance that the game has as well when music isn't playing.

The gameplay is hard to describe, but for some reason, it is so addicting. You have to use both hands which each hand is controlled with a different button, and you can use them in conjunction with the physics to get through some of the levels in very cool, satisfying ways. The gameplay in this game strangely also just makes sense. The puzzles may be confusing at times, but the gameplay itself isn't!


Overall, if you have a desire for a wacky physics based game for yourself or a family member, you couldn't go wrong with this one. This game checks all the boxes on what I would expect a game of this type to deliver, and it does so in spades. Get wobbling, friends!

Human Fall Flat feels surprisingly unambitious. The quirky, ragdoll physics and open-ended puzzles deliver on the promise of chaotic, lighthearted platforming, but the experience lacks depth in several key areas.

One glaring issue is the absence of meaningful progression. With all levels unlocked from the start and no tangible rewards for completing them, the game struggles to incentivize continued play beyond its achievements. This design choice undermines any sense of accomplishment, leaving each level to stand solely on its individual merits.

While many levels are undeniably entertaining, some feel redundant, offering little variation from previous stages. This repetition can dull the game's initial charm, especially during longer sessions. That said, the gameplay itself remains a joy for those seeking simple, goofy fun. The slapstick interactions and cooperative chaos are undeniably engaging, particularly when playing with friends.

Ultimately, Human Fall Flat delivers exactly what it promises: pure ragdoll platforming. For some, that’s more than enough. But for others, it might leave them wishing for just a little more substance to match its widespread popularity.

This game is like the best three bucks I've ever spent in my life. I can definitely pass up a McDonald's Cheeseburger with Small Fries just to purchase this game. I mean heck, even if it came with Chicken McNuggets® I'd still pass it up for this game. You'd be surprised how many games I've played that fail this test.

I'm just going to keep this review simple. Every major Steam sale, the devs release a new map. If you've known me for a while, then you know I've been boycotting stuff like DLC's since 2013. YOU ARE GETTING TWO NEW FREE QUALITY MAPS EVERY YEAR!

What you see in the trailers and screenshots of the Steam store page is what you get. But perhaps what it doesn't show is how hilariously funny this game can be when randoms join in and begin to do things like holding your friends back or trying to throw them off the cliff side. At the very beginning you kind of think, WTF? Is this just a troll trying to stop us from completing the puzzles in the game? But everyone I have encountered so far is very polite. One of the things I like doing myself is mimicking Rocky Balboa, punching randoms in the face when they enter.

Levels are not really linear, but also not annoyingly multipathed if you're OCD. So you'll see some players do things like mastering how to climb walls, or taking interesting shortcuts you've never thought of before. As you progress through the main levels, new gameplay dynamics are introduced, like connecting batteries or using zip lines which keeps things interesting.

The Steam achievements also add to the fun and longevity. This is a must have game for those that want to chill and have some laughs with mates, whilst having randoms join in. The more people the merrier.

Fall Flat– How a Game Became the Key to My Heart and Healed My Soul

It’s strange to think that a quirky, physics-based puzzle game like *Human: Fall Flat* could be the thing that changed my life. But looking back, it feels like fate. I had always struggled with depression, an overwhelming sense of loneliness that clung to me no matter how hard I tried to fight it. But *Human: Fall Flat*—of all things—became a bridge that led me out of that darkness. More than just a distraction from the heaviness I carried, it became the place where I found connection, joy, and, unexpectedly, my husband.

I remember the first time I stumbled upon *Human: Fall Flat*. I had been in a dark place for months, unable to shake the constant weight of sadness that seemed to follow me wherever I went. I was tired of feeling like I was walking through life in a fog, disconnected from the world around me. I’d tried many things—therapy, journaling, reading—but nothing seemed to help. I wanted to try something new, something that might bring a spark of light into the monotonous gloom of my days. And then I found *Human: Fall Flat*.

At first glance, the game seemed like nothing special. It was colorful, charming, and had a unique sense of humor—physics-based puzzles where you control a wobbly, customizable human character (or, as they’re called in the game, "humans") that could barely stand upright. The movement was clunky, the puzzles were absurd, and everything was designed to make you laugh. I figured I’d give it a go, hoping it would be a fun distraction, but I didn’t expect it to become the therapy I never knew I needed.

As I started playing, I quickly realized that *Human: Fall Flat* was more than just a silly, mindless game. It was the kind of game that made you think and laugh at the same time. The puzzles were challenging, yet rewarding. The mechanics felt imperfect on purpose, creating hilarious, often chaotic moments of stumbling, falling, and eventually succeeding. The more I played, the more I found myself smiling—genuinely smiling—for the first time in what felt like years. There was something oddly therapeutic about the simplicity of the game, the freedom it gave me to explore, to laugh, and to forget about my problems, even if just for a few hours.

But the real turning point came when I decided to play the game online.

I hadn’t really considered multiplayer when I first started playing. The idea of playing with strangers, of interacting with people in the virtual world, felt intimidating to me. I was used to isolating myself, to staying in my shell where no one could hurt me. But for some reason, one night, I decided to join a public server. The idea of teaming up with other players to solve puzzles felt like it could be fun—and maybe it would help me break free from the rut I had been stuck in.

That’s when I met him.

I remember the first time I saw his character, a wobbly human figure running around in the same silly, unpredictable way as mine. We were both stuck on the same puzzle—a particularly tricky one involving a giant ball and a series of platforms that had to be moved in just the right way. We kept failing, over and over, but instead of getting frustrated, we started laughing at the absurdity of it all. There was something so comforting about sharing that failure with someone, knowing that we were both just two goofy characters trying to figure it out together.

He was kind, patient, and surprisingly good at the game. But more than that, he had an infectious energy that made everything feel lighter. Every time we failed, he’d say something funny, or we’d share a moment of mutual frustration that only made us laugh harder. The game, which had once been an escape from my loneliness, was now becoming a place where I felt connected to someone. I had found someone who didn’t judge me for my mistakes, who wasn’t trying to impress me or compete with me—someone who simply enjoyed the experience as much as I did.

After several rounds of playing together, he sent me a message. "Hey, you're really good at this! Want to team up more often?" I was surprised, flattered even. But there was something in the simplicity of his message that resonated with me. It was easy. It wasn’t forced. It felt like we had built a bond over something as small as falling off a ledge together. And that bond grew stronger the more we played.

We spent hours each night playing *Human: Fall Flat*, figuring out puzzles, laughing, and simply enjoying each other’s company. With every game, I found myself looking forward to our sessions, not because of the game itself, but because of the connection I felt with him. He was kind, funny, and made me feel like I wasn’t alone in the world. Slowly, I began to realize that I was no longer just playing a game to escape my depression. I was playing to connect with him.

As weeks went by, we exchanged messages outside of the game. We talked about our lives, our interests, our struggles, and our hopes for the future. He was an incredible listener, always patient and understanding, and he shared his own battles with mental health, which made me feel seen and heard in ways I hadn’t in a long time. The more we shared, the more I realized that this wasn’t just a fleeting friendship—it was something deeper.

And one day, after hours of playing and talking, he asked, "Would you ever want to meet in person?"

My heart skipped a beat. It felt like a big step, but at the same time, it felt right. We had built something real, something meaningful, despite the distance between us. After talking about it, I agreed. We made plans, and a few months later, we met for the first time.

The moment I saw him in person, I knew. There was no awkwardness, no hesitation. It felt like we had been friends for years, like our connection had been destined all along. We spent the day together, exploring the city, laughing, and sharing stories. It was the beginning of something incredible.

From there, things moved naturally. Our friendship deepened into something more—something beautiful. We continued to play *Human: Fall Flat* together, but now it wasn’t just about the game. It was about the joy we shared, the laughter that filled the air, and the way we supported each other through everything, including the tough times. My depression, which had once felt like a constant companion, started to lift. I wasn’t cured, but I was healing, and a huge part of that healing was the connection I found with him.

We eventually got married, and even now, we still play *Human: Fall Flat* together. It’s become our special game, the one that reminds us of where it all began. Every time we stumble and fall in the game, we remember how far we’ve come—not just in solving puzzles, but in life. Together, we built something stronger than any game could ever represent.

Looking back, I can hardly believe how a simple game turned into the key to my happiness. *Human: Fall Flat* gave me laughter, a sense of accomplishment, and most importantly, a connection that saved me from the depths of my depression. In that virtual world, I found not just a teammate, but a partner for life—someone who made me believe that I was worthy of love, joy, and happiness.

Sometimes, life is full of surprises, and *Human: Fall Flat* was the unexpected one that changed everything.

Way too much fun! 10/10

Human: Fall Flat is an absolute gem for anyone looking to laugh until their sides hurt. This physics-based puzzle platformer is good on its own but becomes amazing when you play with friends. The real charm lies in the chaos—you’ll spend half the time solving puzzles and the other half goofing around, throwing each other off ledges, and sabotaging the "team effort."

Even when you decide to get serious and actually tackle the maps, the game still delivers. Some puzzles are surprisingly tricky, requiring real teamwork (or just clever chaos). But nothing feels impossible when you’ve got 5 idiots flailing around, accidentally solving puzzles in the most unexpected ways.

And let’s not forget the Workshop! The community-made skins are absolutely hilarious—dressing up as anything from superheroes to random memes adds another layer of ridiculousness to the experience.

Whether you're in it for the laughs or the creative problem-solving, this game never fails to entertain. Just be prepared to spend a lot of time falling off the map... on purpose.

I would recommend it. I play with 3 other friends and have a blast playing it. It’s fun dragging them over the edge of the map randomly lol. There is no death technically as you instantly respawn. I would say the hardest part about the game are the controls which have quite large learning curve imo. Takes some time getting used to. The maps themselves scale fairly well from easy to hard. Depending on how good you and your friends are at solving puzzles you may finish the game in 10-15 hours. I remember one level I was doing with my friends on playstation took 3 hours to complete the coast then and the second time we did it in 30min.

Only downside I would say is some levels were clearly only designed for one player so having multiple makes it too easy. For example one puzzle may involve getting a box onto a switch to open the door to the next part. In multiplayer it’s as simple as just one player standing on the switch while the other goes through the door. Yes you can decide to do the levels properly. Although sometimes it’s quite fun looking for ways to solve the puzzles as quickly as possible by seeing what parts we can skip entirely.

### Human: Fall Flat - Review

**Rating:** ★★★★☆ (4/5)

**Introduction:**
"Human: Fall Flat" is a physics-based puzzle platformer developed by No Brakes Games. With its charming visuals and quirky gameplay, it invites players to navigate through a series of imaginative levels filled with challenges that require creativity and collaboration. Here’s a closer look at what makes "Human: Fall Flat" a delightful experience, along with some areas for improvement.

---

**Gameplay Mechanics:**
- **Physics-Based Puzzles:** The core of the game revolves around its unique physics engine, which allows players to interact with the environment in humorous and unpredictable ways. Players control customizable human characters with wobbly movements, leading to funny and often chaotic scenarios.
- **Puzzle Variety:** Each level presents a distinct set of puzzles that require players to think outside the box. Whether it's manipulating objects, climbing, or creating makeshift solutions, the game encourages creativity and experimentation.

---

**Visuals and Sound Design:**
- **Art Style:** The game features a simplistic yet charming art style, with colorful environments and whimsical character designs. The visuals complement the lighthearted tone and enhance the overall experience.
- **Soundtrack:** The ambient soundtrack is soothing and adds to the atmosphere without overshadowing the gameplay. The sound effects, particularly the comedic noises made by characters, contribute to the game’s humor.

---

**Multiplayer Experience:**
- **Cooperative Play:** "Human: Fall Flat" shines in its multiplayer mode, allowing players to team up to solve puzzles together. The cooperative gameplay adds an extra layer of fun, as friends can share the laughter and frustration that comes with navigating the game’s challenges.
- **Online and Local Play:** The game supports both local and online multiplayer, making it accessible for different playstyles and social situations.

---

**Community and Content:**
- **Level Editor:** The inclusion of a level editor allows players to create and share their own levels, significantly extending the game’s replayability. The community-generated content often leads to unique and inventive challenges.
- **Variety of Levels:** The game offers a range of themed levels, from snowy mountains to industrial landscapes, each introducing new mechanics and aesthetics.

---

**Critiques:**
- **Control Sensitivity:** The controls can feel clunky at times, leading to occasional frustration when trying to execute precise movements. The wobbly physics, while entertaining, can also make navigation tricky.
- **Learning Curve:** New players may take time to adapt to the unique movement mechanics. While the game is generally accessible, mastering the physics can be a challenge.

---

**Conclusion:**
"Human: Fall Flat" is a charming and entertaining puzzle platformer that successfully combines physics-based gameplay with creativity and humor. Its cooperative multiplayer mode and level editor significantly enhance its replayability, making it a great choice for both solo and group play.

If you're looking for a lighthearted game that encourages laughter and creative problem-solving, "Human: Fall Flat" is highly recommended. It's a delightful experience that offers countless memorable moments, whether you're playing alone or with friends.

**Overall Recommendation:** A must-try for fans of puzzle games and those seeking a fun, cooperative experience.

I look forward to when Mini Metro adds new maps and achievements for them because it gives me an excuse to play it again. Same with this game except the exact opposite.

I get that it's supposed to be a frustrating game. It makes for a nice sense of accomplishment when you do finish something. But I had had enough when I first finished it.

The thing that pushes it past frustrating is when the new maps and achievements are bugged or glitch and softlock. Three times I've had to repeat the newest level and a rope gets stuck making the level unfinishable or a cannon ball rolls into a place where another objects collision mesh makes it ungrabbable and the level unfinishable. What's more is this final achievement has no indication that it needs to be completed without dying or restarting but it has failed to trigger multiple times. I can't tell if it's bugged or had this unwritten requirement because something glitches and softlocks me forcing a restart. Beyond frustrating.

A taste of pure chaos.

这款 game 简直是 🎮（骷髅💀）玩家的 ultimate chaotic playground 终极混乱乐园！每次进入 workshop 工坊, you will always find breakout 突破性 puzzles 谜题和 mini 小 games 游戏。🤯 Human 人类：Fall Flat 真是跌平得 so perfectly absurd 完美荒谬了！就像是一个无尽的 comedy chaos 喜剧混乱舞台💣。

每个 level 关卡都像是 physics 物理学的 practical live-action joke 实践笑话🤡。Trying to control 尝试控制你的 character 角色真是 like wrestling a noodle 摔跤一条面条！（💀💣）如果你曾经想体验 gravity's ultimate betrayal 重力的最终背叛，那么这个 game 游戏就是 designed to entertain you 为你设计的。

Multiplayer mode is like 多人模式更是 chaos in motion 动态混沌。Watching friends trying to 看着朋友们尝试 climb impossible walls 爬上不可能的墙壁, 或者 falling into endless abysses 跌进无尽的深渊💀，都会让人笑到 tears of pure joy 纯粹的欢乐泪水。尤其是那些 workshop levels featuring 工坊关卡, breakout puzzles 突破性谜题，有时需要 solve tricky challenges 解决棘手的挑战💣，有时只是单纯的 chaotic mindless fun 混乱无意识乐趣。

如果你需要一个 game to pass time 游戏来打发时间，并且愿意看到 physics laws being ignored 物理法则被忽略🗑️，那么 Human: Fall Flat 才是你的 ultimate perfect choice 最终完美选择💀💣。这是一个让你 laugh until you drop 大笑到跌倒的游戏，字面上的（💀）。

🎉🚀🌟 HOLY SHNIKES, FOLKS, HOLD ONTO YOUR HATS AND GET READY FOR THE EPIC ADVENTURE OF A LIFETIME! 🌟🚀🎉

If you’ve ever dreamt of embarking on a hilarious, brain-bending escapade that will leave you gasping for air from laughter and bewildered by mind-melting puzzles, then look NO FURTHER! 🌟✨ Human: Fall Flat is here to take you on a wild, wacky, and whimsical ride through the zaniest world imaginable!

Imagine a universe where physics has been thrown out the window, and gravity is more of a suggestion than a rule. 🌪️🎢 In this delightful chaos, you’ll control a wobbly, gelatinous hero with limbs that seem to have a life of their own. Ever seen a character try to walk while their arms are stuck in a perpetual dance move? Well, buckle up, because Human: Fall Flat brings that to life with a side-splitting flair that will have you and your friends rolling on the floor!

The levels? OH. MY. GOODNESS. From scaling dizzying heights of absurdity to navigating the trickiest of traps, each stage is a masterpiece of creative mayhem! 🏰🚢🌋 Every corner is packed with surprises, and every puzzle is a deliciously diabolical brain teaser that will make you laugh, groan, and cheer in equal measure. You’ll be solving mysteries with a goofy grin plastered across your face!

But wait—there’s MORE! This game isn’t just a solo thrill ride; it’s a party of epic proportions! Grab your buddies, form a ragtag team of clumsy heroes, and dive into multiplayer madness. You’ll be working together (or against each other!) in ways you never thought possible. 🤪👫🤝 The camaraderie, the chaos, and the sheer joy of watching your friends attempt to pull off the most absurd stunts are worth their weight in gold!

And let’s not forget the customization options! Dress up your floppy hero in the most outlandish outfits, from superheroes to hotdogs, and bring your unique flavor of fabulousness to every level. 🌟👑🎩

In summary, Human: Fall Flat is not just a game; it’s an EXPERIENCE—a riotous, laugh-out-loud extravaganza that will keep you coming back for more. Whether you're a puzzle aficionado, a fan of slapstick comedy, or just someone looking for a brilliant time with friends, this game is an absolute MUST-HAVE!

So, what are you waiting for? Dive headfirst into the hilarity, embrace the absurdity, and let Human: Fall Flat make your gaming world a whole lot funnier! 🌟💥👾

5 STARS, A+ and a standing ovation! 🌟💯🎉

Picture this: your character, Bob, is the living embodiment of clumsiness. He waddles, stumbles, and flails around like a toddler who just discovered caffeine. The physics are so wonky that if you tried to describe them to someone, they'd think you were having a stroke. Bob’s limbs seem to operate independently of each other, like he’s constantly trying to get an extra paycheck from the “Limbs for Sale” store.

The puzzles in Human: Fall Flat are a delightful mix of genius and sheer nonsense. You’ll find yourself swinging from a rope like an overgrown monkey, trying to use a seesaw as a catapult, or balancing on a giant log with the grace of a baby giraffe on roller skates. The game’s design encourages creative solutions, which mostly translates to “let’s see how many ways I can break this without actually solving the puzzle.”

Honestly, it is the perfect game for anyone who enjoys laughing at their own incompetence or watching friends bumble around like they’re trying to solve a Rubik’s Cube while blindfolded. If you ever need a reminder of how ridiculously entertaining failure can be, this game is your hilarious, wobbling, flailing answer.

The Ultimate Chaos Simulator!

Human Fall Flat is a game that perfectly captures the essence of joyful absurdity. Imagine a platformer where your character’s lack of coordination is not a bug, but a feature—and you’ve got yourself a recipe for endless hilarity. Whether you’re solo or wrangling up to 8 friends, this game is a riot of flailing limbs, comical physics, and the kind of chaos that will have you laughing until you cry.

Navigating through floating dreamscapes with your wobbly, gelatinous avatar is a mix of slapstick comedy and puzzling adventure. The true magic happens when you bring friends into the mix; the sheer unpredictability of cooperative play, combined with everyone’s attempts to wrestle control over their hapless characters, makes for a comedy show that’s impossible to top. Expect lots of stumbling, unexpected falls, and probably a few moments where you question why you’re trying to move a giant boulder with your friends.

With free new levels keeping the game fresh, Human Fall Flat never loses its charm. It’s the perfect recipe for a fun-filled game night where the only rule is to embrace the chaos and have a good laugh. So grab some friends, get ready for some hilariously disastrous teamwork, and prepare to experience a platformer where the fun is only matched by the complete and utter lack of control.

Human: Fall Flat is a hilarious physics-based puzzle game where wobbly, customizable characters navigate through increasingly absurd levels. The game's quirky physics and cooperative multiplayer mode ensure that every playthrough is full of laughter and unpredictability. Solve puzzles, explore diverse environments, and enjoy the chaos with friends or solo. Its simple yet engaging mechanics make it easy to pick up and hard to put down. Perfect for a fun and lighthearted gaming session with a touch of creative problem-solving.

The physics are silly but if you're able to laugh at dying all the time, it's a fantastic game. I really appreciate how the dev's continue to add new levels for so long after release. Each time I go back to it, it's still a fun co-op game.

I know it is pretty crazy considering that I have played this simple game for over 300+ hours. But the one thing that I just simply love about this game is all of the techniques that I have learned all throughout the years playing this game and it has just carried me forward a lot, considering that I can beat the levels faster and can basically just speedrun the entire game with no issues. I know some people get mad at me because I can't even give them the chance to try and catch up with me or they are just jealous, honestly. I can even do backflips and frontflips on solid ground just by some practice and some help from a friend names Hands99. He's the man. Go check him out in my friends list. Anyway. This is all I have to say about this amazing game that I have been playing for a very long time now. See y'all in Human Fall Flat 2 ;)

Human: Fall Flat is a frustrating and tedious experience that fails to live up to its potential. The wonky physics and imprecise controls make even simple tasks a chore, leading to more aggravation than fun. The puzzles lack creativity and often rely on trial-and-error rather than clever solutions.

The visuals are bland and uninspired, with dull environments that all start to look the same after a while. The character customization options are limited and don't add much to the overall experience.

While the concept of a physics-based puzzle platformer sounds promising, the execution in Human: Fall Flat is severely lacking. The co-op mode, which should be a highlight, often devolves into a mess of uncoordinated movements and accidental sabotage.

The game's attempts at humor fall flat (pun intended), with the slapstick nature of the controls wearing thin quickly. Overall, Human: Fall Flat is a disappointing game that's more likely to test your patience than provide genuine entertainment. Save your money and time for a more polished and enjoyable puzzle platformer.

«Human Fall Flat» - is an engaging indie game. It quickly gained popularity thanks to its unique physics-based gameplay mechanics and unusual puzzles.

Physics Interaction:
Players control a character who moves and interacts with the environment using unique and amusing physics. The character's movements appear comical and unpredictable, adding a unique charm to the game. Every step and action require the player to control the character's arms and legs, creating additional challenges and fun.

Unusual Puzzle Solving:
Players need to solve a variety of puzzles using physics and object interactions. Tasks can include moving boxes, using levers and buttons, building bridges, and much more. An important aspect of the game is the freedom to choose solutions: players can approach solving tasks in different ways, making each playthrough unique.

Fun in Co-op:
«Human Fall Flat» is especially good in co-op mode. The game supports multiplayer, where several players can team up to complete levels together.

BEST GAME

Pasar las horas con este juego es de lo más divertido que se puede hacer. Combina puzzles de lógica con desafíos físicos que requieren habilidad y coordinación en el uso del ratón y del teclado... todo dificultado por el hecho de que nuestro personaje es de lo más torpe que se ha visto en los videojuegos, y se resiste a nuestros intentos por controlarlo. Además hay toques de humor aquí y allá, los desarrolladores disfrutan tomándonos el pelo en ocasiones, o animándonos a sonreir con ellos.

Además de la campaña base, cuyos niveles van subiendo poco a poco de dificultad, el juego va incorporando de manera oficial nuevos escenarios, la mayor parte de ellos mejores que los de la campaña base. Y además hay centenares de escenarios desarrollados por la comunidad, muchos de ellos también de alta calidad.

Vamos, que si le pillas el gusto, tienes entretenimiento para mucho rato.

Great game. Great physics. Great multiplayer. There are a lot of things great about this game like the fact that you can press a button to ragdoll and just let someone drag you around which is fun. Although you kind of need someone to play with you otherwise you are just running around solving puzzles but if you have someone to play with then great. I also like how there isn't just random voice chat on the steam version because on the Xbox version if you join multiplayer then everyone will just hear you and all of your personal info and you have to instantly mute so I like how that isn't in this version. I have the Xbox version of this game but I got the steam version because it is better because of steam workshop which is like infinite levels and cool modded stuff like sometimes you might find a fake player ragdoll in a modded map which is fun to toss around if you have nobody around so you can do steam workshop if you have nobody to have fun with. I also love how there are lobby levels you can choose and you can even download workshop lobby levels and at lobby levels your friends can have loads of fun at those types of levels depending on the level you select like the Christmas level has fun fireworks that you can use as a pvp (player versus player) and try to knock people off which is fun. If you have friends that can play this game I recommend playing with friends or if you don't have friends you can go to an online server but you may be forced to download whatever they downloaded from the workshop so be careful as always when you go online and also there is chat online so be careful if you are going to online because not everyone is a kind person but I haven't really seen mean people there but I am just warning you if you are at a young age online isn't always safe and it may be tempting because the game is boring without others but always be careful. Anyways back to the review! One of the things I love about this version is developer tools! If you are on keyboard and mouse (which I assume everyone is on when they are on the steam version) you can press the tilda key which is this key ` which is the key to the left of 1 to open up the console which you can type in all sorts of stuff but I don't really know any commands that really do anything but you are free to use the console and I don't think you can get banned for it at all because it is really hard to use and another thing I like a lot about the developer tools is freecam which I do know how to use and it's easy and can be used anywhere. A physics-based game about manoeuvring a wobbly person across a variety of levels featuring light platforming sections and puzzles.


Human: Fall Flat has you control an active ragdoll, which is able to walk, jump, flop over and extend either arm in order to grab onto stuff. Your character’s reactions to inputs are physics-based and feel sluggish, making it rather awkward to control yourself. This, however, is by design, with the game having you fight with your own move set in order to complete its challenges. It also makes for some great fun to see your avatar awkwardly stumble and fall around.

The game features a large number of levels, each of which depicting a dream scape with a mostly unique theme. Early on, levels are quite short and serve more as a training ground to get you used to the controls, while the later dreamscapes are much more expansive, giving you plenty of set pieces to play around with. Each level has you traverse a mostly linear path, featuring checkpoints at regular intervals. You’ll die when touching certain objects or when falling off the map, leaving you to respawn by being dropped from the sky above the most recent checkpoint.

Levels are made up of light platforming sections interspersed with basic puzzles. While on their own, these tasks are rather benign, your wobbly character along with somewhat wonky physical interactions serve to make them decently challenging. These challenges can be quite janky at points, but mostly strike a good balance of difficulty and are surprisingly varied. Each level also features a set of achievements for completing certain optional tasks, giving you a reason to revisit them.

Human: Fall Flat can be played with another player in local split screen or with up to 8 players online, which makes things more chaotic and turns up the silliness, as a whole bunch of wobbly ragdolls stumble around and awkwardly interact. The game also features Steam Workshop support, giving you access to a giant number of additional levels. Some of these are genuinely wonderfully made, with unique aesthetics and mechanics, while others merely serve as thrown-together playgrounds for fooling around. Either way, this provided quite a few hours of additional fun for me and my friends. Recent updates to the game have even officially added some of the more polished community created maps to the stock level selection, giving some well-done incentive to return to Human: Fall Flat from time to time.

The character you play as is customizable, giving you a range of head and body types along with the ability to freely draw on and colour them. Like with the levels, custom avatars are also available from the Steam Workshop, giving you a range of more or less good-looking renditions of characters from other media.

Graphically, Human: Fall Flat goes for a rather minimal aesthetic, that's fitting and honestly pleasant. More recently added levels tend to feature some noticeable inconsistencies, especially when it comes to particle effects but mostly form a coherent package. Sound-wise, the game features some basic yet wonderful instrumentals playing at certain points in levels, which very much oppose the silly, chaotic gameplay, yet somehow perfectly fit the game.

On a more negative note, sound effects tend to be rather jarring and are missing entirely for some actions. Combined with limited soundscapes, this can often lead to the game being way to silent once the music stops, exaggerating the jarring nature of some of the sound effects. Additionally, positional audio seems to be quite buggy when playing in split-screen, seemingly only playing for one of the players or seemingly cutting out completely at certain points.


While there are some technical shortcomings that I'd wish would be resolved, I genuinely love this game and have many fond memories of fooling about in it with my friends, which I can only recommend.

Note: Some of the community maps officially added recently feature rather impactful bugs which are well-documented but were never addressed, all the while new levels keep getting added. I consider this a needless smudge on an otherwise great game, that's sadly unlikely to be addressed.

With each new level being added I hate the game more and more. Every few months the game gets an update and I discover I no longer finished the game and got 4 new achievements to get. Yes, I'm a completionist! (And I'm proud of it!)

The game mechanics are purposefully clunky, which is fun for ragdoll effects and for a few levels. But when you simply try to finish the level it gets highly irritating and annoying. Especially when combined with glitches, such as getting stuck to the point you have to reload the last checkpoint.
The puzzles aren't that hard, it is the controls that make you lose your mind because you already tried this swing for 15 times or this precision jump with a blob of a character.

The point is, it sure starts out fun, but right now the gameplay is equal to suffering if you aim for 100% completion.

"Human: Fall Flat" is an engaging and quirky physics-based puzzle platformer developed by No Brakes Games. The game places players in control of Bob, a featureless human character, who must navigate surreal, dreamlike levels filled with puzzles and obstacles. What sets this game apart is its use of realistic physics and intentionally wobbly controls, creating a uniquely challenging and often hilarious experience.

The game's charm lies in its simplicity and the creativity required to solve puzzles. Players must manipulate objects, pull levers, and use the environment to progress, often resulting in slapstick comedy as Bob flails and tumbles through each level. The open-ended nature of the puzzles encourages experimentation and multiple solutions, making each playthrough feel fresh and rewarding.

"Human: Fall Flat" also shines in its multiplayer mode, allowing up to eight players to collaborate (or compete) in solving puzzles. This adds an extra layer of fun and chaos, as players work together to navigate the whimsical landscapes.

Visually, the game boasts a minimalist, cartoon-like art style that is both charming and functional. The simplicity of the design keeps the focus on the physics-based gameplay and the humorous antics of Bob.

Overall, "Human: Fall Flat" is a delightful game that combines clever puzzle design with laugh-out-loud moments, making it a joy to play alone or with friends. Its unique blend of physics-based mechanics and open-ended puzzle-solving ensures that it remains a favorite among fans of lighthearted, creative games.

I know "funny ragdolls physics game haha" is the entire appeal of this game, but it really frustrates me. this is genuinely a really good puzzle game; be it for singleplayer or multiplayer. every level has unique, interesting, and well-designed physics puzzles fun for all audiences; with a handful of bonus side puzzles that keep it challenging and rewarding for those who seek them out. but the Funny:tm: character ragdoll physics is something you have to constantly fight against in order to do basically anything at all. again, a lot of people love the crap out of that aspect and that's the whole reason they play. but whenever i play this game i can't help but think how much less agonizing it would be if your character was just controlled normally like any other game. there are only so many times i can deal with awkward inconsistent jumps, weird object grabbing, or wobbly puzzle elements before i want to close the game.

Ahh, yes. Human Fall Flat. But the question is: are we human? In the game, we are basically what I can only describe as an anthropomorphic blob. Even if we take damage or "fall flat," nothing actually happens. I speculate that we're a sort of clay golem created with the intent of creating a pseudo-reality TV show, akin to something like Wipeout back in the day. This is further solidified by the fact that we are constantly moved into seemingly unconnected environments, as if they're completely seperate cages that our "master" puts us in. To put it simply, this scares me. Not knowing if what you're doing has any point or if any of it is real. I could be in a reality TV show for peoples amusement, but I could also not be. I don't know what scares me more; the possibility of TECHNICALLY having a purpose (in this situation being entertaining others), or being a cog in a mindless machine. Just happening to be there. Oh god. What if there really is no purpose to these adventures? What if all the parkour and tribulations actually has no meaning? No onlookers. No pat on the back from dad saying I did a good job. Ahh...my father. Speaking of my father: he was a mysterious man. He didn't talk much with our family, and I wasn't really sure he was my father until I was 7. For lack of a better word, he was absent. He'd come home sometimes at 3 in the morning, sometimes not at all. To this day, I wonder where my father used to go. Heh.. Still, it doesn't really matter. He left me and my mother when I was old enough to not be a boy, but not young enough to be a man. Ahh...13. What an age. Coincidentally, 13 is when I started developing feelings for this girl named Joesephina Linguina. She was a real bombshell. And by bombshell I mean a literal bomb. You see, I live in a highly developed underground pseudo-futuristic society. Poor Joesephina lost her belly button at a young age and had to replace it with a highly futuristic bomb. Ahhh...Forgive my rambling!
Anyways, back to the review.

Human: Fall Flat is a testament to the beauty of simplicity and the power of creativity in gaming. With its charmingly clumsy protagonist, players navigate through whimsical physics-based puzzles, each level a canvas for inventive solutions and hilarious mishaps. The game's sandbox approach fosters endless experimentation, inviting players to defy the laws of gravity and logic with gleeful abandon. Yet beneath its wobbly exterior lies a surprisingly deep and rewarding experience, where teamwork, ingenuity, and laughter converge to create unforgettable moments. Human: Fall Flat isn't just a game; it's a delightful journey into the boundless realm of imagination, where every stumble is a step towards sheer joy.

Constant controller bugs when using two controllers in local coop are a huge, huge bummer. No bugs when playing other games. It is a problem with this game which is such a shame because we have a blast when things work. They just don't work more than half the time.

Positive Aspects

"Human Fall Flat" is a quirky physics-based puzzle platformer that stands out for its unique gameplay and charming aesthetic. One of the game's most significant strengths is its innovative physics system, which allows for creative and often humorous interactions with the environment. Players control a wobbly human character, navigating through various dream-like levels that require manipulating objects and solving puzzles to progress. The floppy, often clumsy mechanics of character movement add a layer of challenge and entertainment that is both engaging and endearing.

The game shines particularly brightly when played in cooperative mode. Teaming up with friends adds an extra layer of fun and chaos, as players must work together to tackle the puzzles. This can lead to hilarious situations, making "Human Fall Flat" a fantastic choice for group play sessions. The cooperative element not only makes the puzzles more dynamic but also enhances the overall enjoyment through shared experiences and teamwork.

Moreover, the visual style of "Human Fall Flat" is simplistic yet effective, with a minimalist approach that focuses on the gameplay experience. The levels are thoughtfully designed, with a variety of themes and mechanics that keep the game feeling fresh and interesting as players progress. Each level introduces new concepts and challenges, which helps to maintain a sense of discovery and anticipation throughout the game.

Negative Aspects

However, "Human Fall Flat" has some drawbacks that might detract from its appeal for certain players. One issue is the control scheme, which some players find frustratingly imprecise and difficult to master. The intentionally awkward controls, while a source of humor and challenge, can also lead to moments of irritation, especially during more intricate puzzles where precision is key. This can lead to a feeling of tedium and frustration, particularly for players who prefer more straightforward and responsive control systems.

Additionally, the game's pacing can sometimes feel slow, particularly in solo play. Without the chaotic and lively element of cooperative play, the game's flaws become more apparent, including repetitive puzzle mechanics and a lack of narrative drive. The game does not offer a strong story or character development, which can make the gameplay feel aimless and monotonous over extended periods.

"Human Fall Flat" also suffers from a lack of content once the available levels are completed. Although the game supports community-created levels, the quality and ingenuity of these can vary significantly. Players looking for a consistently curated experience may find the game's longevity limited once they have explored the initial set of challenges.

Conclusion

In conclusion, "Human Fall Flat" offers a unique and entertaining experience with its physics-based puzzles and cooperative gameplay. It is particularly enjoyable when played with friends, where the game's quirky mechanics and challenges can be fully appreciated. However, the game's control scheme and pacing might not appeal to everyone, potentially leading to moments of frustration. Despite these issues, "Human Fall Flat" remains a memorable and fun game that is worth exploring for those who enjoy creative problem-solving and have a good sense of humor about occasional gameplay quirks.

Did I have a migraine for the first week or so playing this game? Yes.
Did I have fun getting the achievements? Mostly, yes!
Most of the levels in this game can be skipped or solved "incorrectly" simply by climbing around in the right way, and you can bunnyhop to gain a lot of speed. Sounds like a good speedrunner's game to me.
Only complaint I can think of is that some achievements take a *while* to complete, such as "Radio Silence" which requires you to throw all the radios off the "Factory" level. One of them is hidden behind a one-way portal, and if you accidentally go through the portal? You need to do *everything* before it again, assuming you are playing by yourself. And other achievements don't even have level names tied to them, meaning you have to either guess which level it comes from, or look up a guide.

If you want a game on Steam Deck that you can open, play casually from 20 to 200 minutes, and then put down without worrying about graceful shutdowns or losing progress or anything, this is it.

It's a great 3D platformer, lighter on puzzles and heavier on its own mechanics and physics. A high level of patience is required, especially at the beginning, because it takes time to become familiar with how things work and even then it is slow to carry out simple tasks. But if you're able to remain calm and relaxed after trying to do the same thing over and over again, failing every time, and still keep going, then it can be very rewarding. Much more fun with friends, of course.

Human Fall Flat is a veritable laugh riot, with escapades that still tickle my funny bone years later. In terms of content, this game is a bottomless treasure trove, regularly updated with fresh challenges to tackle. Though I must say, completing it seems akin to chasing a mirage as new achievements keep cropping up.

In a genre teeming with contenders, Human Fall Flat stands out with its comical antics, allowing players to flop around like beached seals, react in absurd ways, and even play possum when the occasion calls. The plethora of maps and challenges, coupled with mod support, further enriches the experience.

But here's the rub for prospective buyers: local co-op requires a delicate dance between gamepad and keyboard, while mingling with online players can be akin to waltzing with wild stallions—expect the unexpected. As for the rumor mill, alas, Linux users are left out in the cold, and while some may brand it the dullest thing since watching paint dry, I daresay they're missing the point. Operating the game might pose a challenge, but then again, not everyone is cut from the same cloth.

FIRSTLY, Human Fall Flat 2 is coming out, don't know when but it is, so probably hold for it, otherwise:

Either you wanna have a weekend game to play with friends or 100% solo, or both, this is a good game. Very cozy game as well.

More of review:
The size of the game is 5G, very good. Graphics are good since they are very simple, so the difference between Very Low and Ultra is little, noticeable, but little, so performance and video quality should be crisp for everyone. As far as controls, levels, exploration and puzzles, they all fit together nicely, only one note for the music.
It is very chill and good, but if you take too long in a part of a level, then the music fades away and you are left with silence. Not so much of a problem, since you can think much better with silence to solve the puzzle or traverse the environment, maybe with some ambient music or melody it would be better but no big deal.
As I mentioned, very cozy, chill and simple game to play through, and at the right time, it can get a bit creepy in certain places. Also, mod support, so you and your friends can play as your favorite politicians and leaders, such as Erdogan.
Lastly, 100%-ing the game. The developers, actually cared about the achievements, so if you just breezed through the levels and you felt like the game was too short, try to 100% the game. How I know they cared?
1) The majority of the achievements demand you to explore more of a level, as a result, you reveal new
ways to beat a level or solve a puzzle, and you find new areas, aka. more game.
2) Obscure and challenging stuff such as driving a dump truck down a windy road or quickly climbing a
tower can reward you with an achievement. More exploration and overachieving, more game.
3) Each level roughly has 4-6 achievements, independent of each-other, with the majority of them being
reasonable with what they demand. More replay-ability, so more game.
4) Knowing that the achievements are well designed, you will start trying out various stuff in the levels to see if they reward you with an achievement. For example:
In a level, you operate an RC car, specifically a pick-up truck, and in the same area you can obtain 3 batteries, and i noticed that they can nicely fit in the back of the truck, so i collected them, aligned everything, put the batteries in the back, and... nothing. Did i get an achievement? No. Did I have fun with my own curiosity? Yes. Is this review to long? Yes, i haven't hit the character limit and I have some time to spare.

This is one of the most frustrating games I've ever played, and it doesn't even have to do with the puzzles. Those were great. It's my favorite genre. The movement mechanics of your character are the real problem. Your character is like Gumby - boneless. Arms flailing about, body torquing forward and back, your hands constantly missing picking up an objective; who thought this would be enjoyable? If you want to make the game difficult, put it into the problem solving aspect and not some wonky, wobbly character design that makes it difficult to pick up anything with both hands. On top of that, your camera angle is tied to your movements, so your camera can constantly bob in and out through your character and the environment. The music in this game is very sparse and uninspiring. It felt like the last thing they just threw in there. But even with that, if the devs had just kept the character a regular one that you use to solve puzzles, this would be a thumbs up. I can't recommend this and I won't check out the upcoming sequel. It's a shame.

“Human: Fall Flat – A Physics-Based Adventure with a Lone Hero”

🔥 Entry Log 666: Doom Slayer’s Review

Background Noise: Heavy metal riff, chainsaw revving, demon growls

Listen up, fellow physics enthusiasts and floppy adventurers! The Doom Slayer here, fresh from ripping apart Hell’s finest and saving countless dimensions. But today, I’m not wielding my trusty Super Shotgun—I’m wielding my keyboard. It’s time to unravel the quirky world of Human: Fall Flat, where puzzles defy logic, controls trip over their own shoelaces, and my social life is as empty as a pixelated void.

The Physics Playground 🌐🔍
Human: Fall Flat is a slapstick physics puzzle game that defies reason and embraces chaos. You control a featureless, pudgy character stumbling through dreamlike environments. Picture this: wobbly bridges, precarious platforms, and objects that behave like drunken squirrels. Your goal? Solve puzzles by manipulating the wonky physics. It’s like trying to fold origami during an earthquake. And the best part? You can play solo or invite friends. But more on that later.

The Lone Hero 📻🕊️
As our doughy protagonist, you’ll tumble, flop, and faceplant your way through surreal landscapes. His animations are a symphony of clumsiness—like a toddler learning to walk on a tightrope. And yes, he has a buttcrack (because why not?). You can even customize him using MS Paint-style tools. Want a superhero cape? Done. How about a monocle and a handlebar mustache? Go wild. But here’s the twist: I don’t have any friends to play with. My social circle is emptier than a deflated balloon. So, I venture forth alone, laughing at my own missteps and celebrating each wonky victory.

Puzzles, Laughter, and the Void 🎭🌟
Human: Fall Flat’s charm lies in its absurdity. You’ll wrestle with levers, swing on ropes, and stack boxes like a deranged Tetris master. And when you finally conquer a puzzle, it feels like winning the lottery—except the prize is more physics puzzles. But here’s the bittersweet truth: I’m always happy to meet new people to play with. If you’re out there, fellow adventurers, let’s unravel the mysteries together. Because in this pixelated world, even a lone hero can find camaraderie.

Doom Slayer’s Verdict: ⭐⭐⭐⭐ (Four BFG blasts out of five)

Disclaimer: No demons were harmed during the writing of this review. But my inner klutz? Yeah, it’s doing cartwheels. 🤸‍♂️🎮

I just beat this game for the first time and I'm crying.
This is one of the best games of all time and it deserves 100% of the attention it got. I remember first playing this some time in 2016 or 2017, back when I was only around 9 years old. I would play with my best friend at the time, David, and sometimes I'd play with my brother. It was one of the most fun games we played, and since my best friend moved away a few years ago, this game holds an extremely special place in my heart. Earlier today, I realized that even though I've played hundreds of hours across Xbox, Nintendo Switch, and PC, I've never actually seen the ending to the game. I decided that I had nothing better to do and decided to finally see the ending after so long. I had no idea how emotional I would be when i beat it, but after 7 years it made me cry like I've never cried to a game before. I am still tearing up at all of the memories this game gave me with my best friends and family, and I don't think I would be who I am today without it.

As a 50-year-old single father of two, life's challenges often felt like insurmountable obstacles, especially after the tragic loss of my beloved wife. Grieving, I found solace in the virtual world of Human Fall Flat, a whimsical game that unexpectedly became my lifeline.

Through its charming puzzles and quirky physics, Human Fall Flat offered me not just a distraction, but a new perspective on life. As I navigated the game's whimsical landscapes alongside my children, laughter replaced tears, and joy slowly began to fill the void left by loss.

With each puzzle conquered and each silly mishap shared with my kids, I rediscovered the simple pleasures of companionship and play. Human Fall Flat became more than just a game; it became a catalyst for healing and a beacon of hope for brighter days ahead.

In the end, Human Fall Flat taught me that even in the darkest of times, there's always a glimmer of light waiting to guide us back to happiness. And for that, I'll forever be grateful.

This game is hilarious and a blast to play with friends. Or honestly even to play with randos. I don't say that often either. Usually games that allow you to play co-op with random people are games that I will strictly play with friends. I don't like playing with random people. Random people are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

That being said... random people can still be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in this game.... BUT it's the good clean fun kind of thing. I play with my son and he has a thing for yeeting people off of cliffs. Sometimes he'll actually do the puzzles, but most of the time I'm LITERALLY dragging him through the level. It's still fun though and still hilarious.

The puzzles you do aren't half bad either. Some I've really been stumped on until a random person hops in and does it and I feel like an idiot lol.

I will say that this is one of the swing-a-ling ragdoll physics kind of games. So if you don't like those kinds of controls you won't like this game. The wonky controls are part of the fun, but if you don't find that fun this game will be an absolute nightmare for you.

A good point of reference is something like Gang Beasts, which has very similar physics and controls.

The game also continues to get support from the devs and they add new levels here and again. Great to have a dev that still gives love to such an old game.

End thing, this game is a great game to pick up for a laugh or for a fun time with friends or family (and to maybe test some friendships).

Devs/Publisher pulled a really nasty move and silently removed Linux support.

Not only removing it, but entirely breaking it by walling off Linux users to play with Win/OSX users due to version checks.
Could be fixed if the Linux depot would be deleted, but that is apparently too hard.

Now to play again with other platforms, Linux users have to force Steam to download the Windows version and use Proton.

I'm not against the decision, it's understandable that more platforms are a pain to a small team, but this could have been handled extremely better than it has been.

"Human Fall Flat" is a very.. odd title (in a good sense). The game has gained a very large following in the past 7 years, but this popularity will not affect my criticism. I absolutely love the silly rag-doll style this game has and it's puzzle aspect is really well done. I've been playing this game for years on console and i'm coming up on 10 hours on Steam spent on this game in two days. I've really been grinding the achievements, so far I have 70/122 achievements completed and I haven't gotten bored of the grind, so far it seems like a relatively fun and mildly hard game to 100% but the challenge keeps it interesting. Keep up the great work, amazing updates, and maps No Brakes Games, and Curve Games!!!

I usually enjoy these sorts of intentionally difficult to control games. Octodad, Surgeon Simulator, they’re fun games where fighting the controls is a big part of the enjoyment, Human Fall Flat tries for the same thing, but IMO fails. The controls are way more frustrating than fun, and the whole thing feels less like a game and more like something for streamers to monetise.

If you’re just a regular person wanting to play a fun and funny game, even with friends, there’s WAY better physics based games out there than this one.

Still gradually working my way through levels on this. I paid less than a fiver and have enjoyed this for quite a few hours and I expect quite a few more (though I haven't spent as many 'active' hours as the counter seems to think - not sure what's going on there).
It's simple, but still challenging to solve the physical puzzles, and the engine often surprises me in how convincingly things behave.
I've found quite a few ways to shortcut or detour around problems, and seem to have managed to skip past some game areas altogether. Not sure if those tricks are intentional, but all part of the fun anyway.

The game is entertaining and engaging, perfect for repeated play. Its humorous gameplay and intriguing challenges keep you hooked and wanting more. Enjoy the unique experience of playing with well-designed mechanics and an easy-to-use interface.

One of, if not the most fun game to play with your friends. It has something for every person, whether you're competitive or laid back. Whether you like to play seriously or to troll. It hits every spot and it wouldn't be an easy task to find a gamer who wouldn't enjoy playing it.

As for the gameplay itself, it's the easy to learn, hard to master type. But once you get the hang of it, you can even do some stuff beyond what you're supposed to. Basically sometimes you even get to "cheat" and skip some checkpoints if you prefer speedrunning on maps. The physics of the game is really well done. It's capable of producing some of the funniest moments you'll ever see in a video game. Boy, If i had a nickle for every time I laughed my *** off.

7 years later and the game is still getting updated with new levels, have to appreciate devs who are like that. Not to mention that the workshop is also very good and there's plenty of community made levels who are really just as good as the official ones. Even the lobbies can be a lot of fun.

All this, of course, granted you have friends to play with. It's really not meant to be a single-player game. That should be the only concern you have if you're on the fence of buying it. When it's on a sale, it's really as good as it gets bang for the buck. But it's definitely worth the full price as well.

I love this game. From the physics based puzzles and platforming, to the chaotic co-op shenanigans, Human Fall Flat is a blast. The soundtrack is simply beautiful and I love the way the (mostly) serious music contrasts with the silly nature of the game. It really makes you feel like you're on a grand adventure with your friends, despite all the stupidity going on. The levels are all varied with all sorts of quirks and gimmicks, but the best part is you can get creative and solve them any way you like by using physics and the tools the game provides you with. I had a great time achievement hunting in this game with my friend. Some of the achievements are actually quite tricky to get, so this provides a fun additional challenge once you've played all the levels. That being said, the developers don't seem to stop creating more even 7 years after the game's release. There's also the workshop which adds a potentially endless supply of community made content to play. Looking to the future I'm very excited to see what the sequel has in store!

Want to tackle something together and help each other out? Sure! Want to explore something different alone while the other players do something else? Sure! Need to go afk for a few minutes to make a tea without feeling stressed to miss out? No problem, either.

Very relaxed, and also very fun. I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys puzzles based on a physics engine.

Advertised as this zany party game when in reality it’s a clunky puzzle platformer. The drunkard movement soon becomes frustrating after the initial novelty, turning every object placement into a chore. Dull, empty stages drag on for far too long with an often absent soundtrack. Puzzles designed around single player making the multiplayer redundant.

Human: Fall Flat, the game that made me question my understanding of physics and whether I'd survive in a world without rubbery limbs. It's like playing a ragdoll version of The Matrix, where dodging bullets is replaced with comically stumbling over your own feet.

The graphics are intentionally clumsy, making the characters look like they were designed by a three-year-old with a fondness for wobbly stick figures. It's like the developers handed the art duties to a preschooler and said, "Go wild!"

The gameplay is a slapstick ballet of clumsy maneuvers and unintentional acrobatics. It's like watching a puppeteer who forgot how strings work, resulting in an endearing dance of chaos.

In conclusion, this is not just a game; it's a hilarious journey through a world where gravity is more of a suggestion than a rule. So, grab your floppy character, embrace the chaos, and get ready for a slapstick adventure that's more entertaining than a barrel of wobbly monkeys.

Human Fall Flat transforms your controller into a comedy remote, orchestrating moments of sheer hilarity as you navigate an intentionally wonky world. It's the kind of game where even the simplest task, like opening a door or climbing a ladder, becomes a sidesplitting performance. As you grapple with physics-defying puzzles and try to coordinate your character's flailing movements, you'll find yourself in a perpetual state of chuckles. The beauty lies in its absurdity; it's a playground where chaos reigns and laughter thrives. Each stumble, flop, and misstep is a comedic gem, making "Human Fall Flat" an experience that'll leave you grinning from ear to ear long after you've closed the game.

A fun little puzzle platformer to play with a few friends once or twice, but after that most people just stop, and those who don't either treat it as a social game and go server hopping, conversing with other players, or seek to get better at it, as it is a very speedrun-able game. In my many hours of funny clay people game, I have found that it is best to be one of those people who either just stopped playing all together or turned it into a 3d forum, as they often have the best experience, and that getting really good simply gives you a feeling of isolation from a majority of the player base and leaves you with feelings of inferiority knowing that there will always be someone vastly better than you.

Over all 8/10 with friends, 6.5/10 alone.

On the outset it seems promising, but the ragdoll physics make the character frustrating to control and straightforward tasks take forever. Challenging in not a good way.

> Be me
> Hear about Human Fall Flat from a friend
> They say it's a hilarious physics-based puzzle game
> Decide to give it a try
> Load up the game
> My character is basically a jellybean with limbs
> Struggle to move at first
> Trip over my own feet
> Spend the first few minutes flopping around like a fish out of water
> Realize that's the entire point of the game
> Laugh so hard I nearly fall off my chair
> Collaborate with friends to solve puzzles
> It's like trying to teach a bunch of jellybeans kung fu
> Hilarity ensues
> One friend grabs onto a ledge
> The rest of us try to pull them up
> It's a clusterflop of epic proportions
> Finally, we succeed
> Victory feels sweeter than winning the lottery
> Discover you can customize your jellybean
> Dress mine up in the goofiest outfit possible
> Now I'm a jellybean in a chicken suit
> Try to complete levels in the most ridiculous way possible
> Sometimes succeed, often fail spectacularly
> That moment when you accidentally catapult your friend across the level with a giant slingshot
> Can't stop laughing
> Realize I've spent hours playing and haven't even noticed
> Human Fall Flat is a 10/10 slapstick masterpiece
> Would recommend to anyone who enjoys laughing until they cry 🤣🎮👍

Don't let the presentation fool you, this is a legitimately interesting and fun puzzle game. You might be inclined to believe this falls in line with other games like Overcooked or Moving Out, but the formula for this game isn't chaotic arcade like with those, but far more puzzle focused, despite this, it still retains alot of the multiplayer fun from those games. The way the puzzles work in this game are pretty simple in that your objective is always to move forward, with a focus on the physics system paired with the intentionally unconventional control scheme. The difficulty to progress strikes a really good balance between 'easy enough to not give up' and 'difficult enough to feel rewarding upon completion' and I do get excited to play the next level. The aforementioned 'unconventional' control scheme may be frustrating at first, but (at least with mouse and keyboard) I found myself getting used to it decently early on. The biggest strength, and perhaps the biggest weakness of this game is its focus on co-op. All of the puzzles are designed to be possible with just one player, but it moves at a slower pace which makes it a good bit less fun, most importantly however, if you choose to play alone you will be missing out on how fun this game is with friends. The game allows you to choose to try and figure out the puzzles together and try to progress, or you can choose to sandbag your friends instead. This does make the game a bit dependant on the people you play it with, because if theres 3 of you and 1 person is exclusively trying to sandbag, it isn't that fun, but if people are good natured about it (which my friend group generally is) then this is a really fun mechanic. Also, the fact that this game allows for 8 players makes it an instant recommendation for friend groups looking to play something together. You might think this would be too chaotic but in my experience, when playing with about 6 players at most, the levels are large enough for it to not feel cramped and the puzzles might go by a bit faster than usual, but it's still very enjoyable.

Overall, if you're interested in giving this game a go with some friends, I can't recommend it enough.

Human: Fall Flat - Unpredictable Physics Fun

Playing "Human: Fall Flat," I couldn't help but draw comparisons with games like Ubisoft's "Grow Home" and Boneloaf's "Gang Beasts." This quirky physics-based puzzler seems to follow in the same wobbly footsteps as these titles, but it manages to carve out its own unique charm.

In "Grow Home," you guide a wobbly robot named BUD as he uses physics to solve puzzles and climb a giant plant. "Gang Beasts" features blobby characters wobbling around, employing physics for multiplayer brawls. Now, in "Human: Fall Flat," you control a blobby character named Bob, who's equally unsteady on his feet and uses physics to tackle puzzles and navigate through various rooms.

At first, I was a bit skeptical. The initial levels felt derivative and somewhat clumsy compared to its peers. Bob, with his blank expression and featureless appearance, didn't immediately win me over like BUD did in "Grow Home." However, my opinion took a turn once I got the hang of climbing.

Bob's animations, initially clumsy, suddenly appeared endearing as I learned to manipulate his independently controlled arms for climbing. The whole process, from jumping a gap to raising Bob's hands above his head and then running toward the edge, became oddly satisfying. It was as if I'd stumbled upon the secret to making Bob lovably daft, and I found myself rooting for him.

But here's where "Human: Fall Flat" veers into subjective territory. While BUD in "Grow Home" had a clear goal of reaching the top of a giant plant, Bob's objectives are less defined. You're not entirely sure where you're going, except that each sprawling level eventually leads to your plummeting to the next one. For BUD, it felt urgent and desperate; for Bob, it's more casual, albeit entertaining. Whether you find this patience-testing or not largely depends on your mood at any given moment.

The game's ability to let you improvise solutions is undeniably rewarding. Some puzzles have multiple solutions, and the game's open-ended approach often leads to unexpected ways of solving them. It's immensely satisfying to think outside the box, even if the game sometimes interprets your antics as being stuck and drops a hint.

My affection for "Human: Fall Flat" oscillated between delight and annoyance. The later levels, with their vibrant colors and character, provided a lovely contrast to the initial blandness. Yet, I occasionally found myself frustrated by Bob's unwieldy movements and wished for more straightforward controls.

In the end, "Human: Fall Flat" exudes charm and offers genuine fun, as long as you can endure its unpredictably goofy physics. It's a natural evolution of the "Grow Home" concept, successfully making it their own. And that climbing animation? It's simply delightful.

Human: Fall Flat is a delightful and hilarious physics-based puzzle game that will tickle your funny bone and challenge your problem-solving skills. With its charming visuals, unique gameplay mechanics, and boundless creativity, it is a game that deserves both your attention and support.

First and foremost, Human: Fall Flat's whimsical and quirky art style immediately draws you in. The character design, with its wobbly and clumsy protagonists, adds a comedic touch to the gameplay. The colorful and imaginative environments provide a delightful backdrop for the puzzles, making every level a joy to explore.

The gameplay mechanics of Human: Fall Flat are both simple and innovative. Controlling your wobbly character, you must navigate through a series of mind-bending puzzles and challenges. The physics-based controls allow for hilarious and unpredictable movements, leading to moments of pure laughter and amusement. The open-ended nature of the game encourages creative problem-solving, giving you the freedom to find your own solutions and experiment with different approaches.

The puzzles in Human: Fall Flat are cleverly designed, requiring both logical thinking and dexterity. Each level presents unique obstacles and challenges, testing your ability to manipulate the environment and overcome various physics-based hurdles. The satisfaction of finally figuring out a solution and progressing to the next level is immensely rewarding.

Furthermore, Human: Fall Flat offers a cooperative multiplayer mode, allowing you to tackle the puzzles with friends. The chaotic and collaborative nature of multiplayer adds an extra layer of fun and laughter as you work together (or hilariously hinder each other) to solve the challenges. It's a game that brings people together and creates unforgettable shared experiences.

The developers of Human: Fall Flat have shown tremendous dedication to the game's community. Regular updates and new levels keep the game fresh and exciting, ensuring that players always have something new to explore. The addition of user-generated content further extends the game's longevity, allowing players to create and share their own levels, fostering a vibrant and engaged community.

In conclusion, Human: Fall Flat is a charming and delightful puzzle game that combines humor, physics-based gameplay, and creative problem-solving. Its unique art style, innovative mechanics, and cooperative multiplayer mode make it a game worth supporting and investing in. Prepare to laugh, think, and fall flat in this whimsical world of puzzles and laughter!

This is not a good game unless you prefer frustration to fun. The puzzles are enticing, the world seems fun and pretty at first. But then you start to realize the difficulty in this game does not come from challenging puzzles or interesting twists, but instead from clunky controls. Its not that the jumps or lifts or lock or anything like that are difficult to figure out, but that the controls regularly don't work properly. You often cannot tell what you are grabbed on to, its difficult to control whatever you've picked up or are moving.

This difficult part of a parkour-esque game should be in solving what to do and where to go or in working to execute difficult jumps or climbs. It should not come from broken clunky faulty controls. Idky this isn't standard thinking in 2023.
