Human: Fall Flat - Unpredictable Physics Fun

Playing "Human: Fall Flat," I couldn't help but draw comparisons with games like Ubisoft's "Grow Home" and Boneloaf's "Gang Beasts." This quirky physics-based puzzler seems to follow in the same wobbly footsteps as these titles, but it manages to carve out its own unique charm.

In "Grow Home," you guide a wobbly robot named BUD as he uses physics to solve puzzles and climb a giant plant. "Gang Beasts" features blobby characters wobbling around, employing physics for multiplayer brawls. Now, in "Human: Fall Flat," you control a blobby character named Bob, who's equally unsteady on his feet and uses physics to tackle puzzles and navigate through various rooms.

At first, I was a bit skeptical. The initial levels felt derivative and somewhat clumsy compared to its peers. Bob, with his blank expression and featureless appearance, didn't immediately win me over like BUD did in "Grow Home." However, my opinion took a turn once I got the hang of climbing.

Bob's animations, initially clumsy, suddenly appeared endearing as I learned to manipulate his independently controlled arms for climbing. The whole process, from jumping a gap to raising Bob's hands above his head and then running toward the edge, became oddly satisfying. It was as if I'd stumbled upon the secret to making Bob lovably daft, and I found myself rooting for him.

But here's where "Human: Fall Flat" veers into subjective territory. While BUD in "Grow Home" had a clear goal of reaching the top of a giant plant, Bob's objectives are less defined. You're not entirely sure where you're going, except that each sprawling level eventually leads to your plummeting to the next one. For BUD, it felt urgent and desperate; for Bob, it's more casual, albeit entertaining. Whether you find this patience-testing or not largely depends on your mood at any given moment.

The game's ability to let you improvise solutions is undeniably rewarding. Some puzzles have multiple solutions, and the game's open-ended approach often leads to unexpected ways of solving them. It's immensely satisfying to think outside the box, even if the game sometimes interprets your antics as being stuck and drops a hint.

My affection for "Human: Fall Flat" oscillated between delight and annoyance. The later levels, with their vibrant colors and character, provided a lovely contrast to the initial blandness. Yet, I occasionally found myself frustrated by Bob's unwieldy movements and wished for more straightforward controls.

In the end, "Human: Fall Flat" exudes charm and offers genuine fun, as long as you can endure its unpredictably goofy physics. It's a natural evolution of the "Grow Home" concept, successfully making it their own. And that climbing animation? It's simply delightful.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

My partner bought this as a gift for us to play together and I absolutely love it! It did trigger my motion sickness the first time i played it but after a while it got much better. It's incredibly fun to play with my partner and other friends, be it grabbing each other and leaping off the edge or rooting for someone to reach an elusive checkpoint. Amazing game for anyone wanting to experience something new and interesting. It has many levels and puzzles that I really like. It's quite a simple game, too and has no really advanced graphics (not in a bad way). Quite fun to play with friends.

My only downsides are:
1. There is no cross platform play (e.g People who bought Windows store version cannot play with people who bought Steam version)
2. Characters can sometimes glitch out and have for example one leg gone (or when I was playing online, my character got totally stuck and could not move)
3. Most of the "levels" that other people make are in a foreign language and cannot be read by somebody who does not know said foreign language. I would like for the game to have an inbuilt level editor, so that players can edit levels more easily and so that level making is more accessible, especially to platforms outside the Steam version, since for PS4 and Windows store version, there is no community levels.

While I see how Human: Fall Flat could be a lot of fun in multiplayer, especially doing custom levels, the singleplayer gameplay just doesn't do it for me. I realize it's a physics game and that this is intentional, but the player character's lack of maneuverability is inherently frustrating. While the puzzles aren't conceptually difficult, it's not particularly fun to be stuck in a level for a technical reason, even though you've identified the route out and the mechanism by which to get there. It's also easy to get physically stuck on or behind objects. In a group, that frustration can sometimes be funny.

That's not to say this game isn't worthwhile or interesting. I didn't find the puzzles particularly engaging to begin with, but this game isn't really about complicated puzzles: it's about failing to do basic human motion properly (and having fun with that). Admittedly, it is fun at first, even in singleplayer. The physics engine and its whole "flinging yourself around" approach is amusing. It was neat to think about individually coordinating each of your hands to grab objects, climb, move things, etc. Perhaps this is how toddlers feel every day.

Still, it didn't do it for me. An additional pain point is that the way the camera moves is at best disorienting and at worst nausea-inducing. (I don't typically get motion sickness in video games either.) I wasn't engaged by the narrator's remarks and the soundtrack felt out of place. The graphics are intentionally low-poly, and some of the levels are a bit cute, but I felt the plainness was lacking some artistic spark. Performance was perfectly good though!

If you want a game that lets you fool around with your friends, this is it! If you want a more technically playable puzzle game, there are more suitable options out there. Personally, just not my thing.

Human Fall Flat : By Triple F

"Human: Fall Flat", developed by No Brakes Games, is a physics-based puzzle platformer that throws you into the hilariously frustrating world of wobbly, customizable humans. With its simple controls and emphasis on teamwork, it's a game that's perfect for parties and creating unforgettable moments of shared laughter.

The core element of "Human: Fall Flat" lies in its physics engine. Your character, completely lacking in traditional jump buttons or complex controls, relies solely on grabbing and climbing to navigate the environment. This can be both a source of frustration and amusement. While the controls are undeniably simple, mastering them proves to be a hilarious challenge. Expect flailing limbs, unexpected tumbles, and moments where your carefully constructed human tower collapses in a fit of giggles.

The game offers a variety of levels with varying degrees of complexity, each presenting a unique puzzle that requires you to reach a specific goal. While you can attempt these solo, the true magic of "Human: Fall Flat" shines in its multiplayer mode. Playing with up to eight players online opens up a world of chaotic possibilities. Working together to solve puzzles becomes a hilarious exercise in communication and coordination, as you grapple, climb, and (often unintentionally) fling each other towards the objective. However, be warned: the game also lends itself to friendly sabotage, as players can easily send their teammates tumbling off ledges or into precarious situations, adding a layer of unpredictable humor to the experience.

"Human: Fall Flat" allows for a surprising amount of character customization. You can choose from a variety of head shapes, body types, and outfits, allowing you to create your own unique "wobbly human" persona. While the customization don't affect gameplay, they add a layer of personality and humor to the experience, especially when viewed alongside the game's physics engine, where even the most serious-looking character can end up in a hilariously awkward situation.

The game's visual style is deceptively simple. The world is built from basic shapes and textures, with a focus on functionality over visual fidelity. However, this minimalist approach perfectly complements the game's core gameplay. The lack of visual clutter allows players to focus on the physics and the hilariously unpredictable movements of their characters, further enhancing the overall experience.

"Human: Fall Flat" can also be completed individually in a few hours, depending on your skill and level of persistence. However, the game's true strength lies in its multiplayer functionality. Spending an evening with friends navigating the game's challenges and reveling in the shared laughter is where "Human: Fall Flat" truly shines.

To conclude, "Human: Fall Flat" is a unique and entertaining experience, particularly for those looking for a game to play with friends. The combination of simple controls, hilarious physics, and cooperative (or chaotically competitive) gameplay creates an experience that's both challenging and side-splitting. While the short length and potentially frustrating controls might not be for everyone, the game offers an undeniable charm and the potential for countless funny moments that will stay with you long after you finish the final level.

It's like Dark Souls but because of puzzles and "parkour".
You try again and again, fail, fall, struggle until you complete one puzzle. And then there is the next one.
The game also lacks a bit of interesting gameplay mechanics for this length. You do pretty much the same at the end of the game as you did at the beginning.
Also even though the game features a local-coop mode there is absolutely no reason to play it in co-op. All the levels are designed to be completed solo so one of the players will probably get bored if the other one will be taking the initiative or will be better at climbing.
The music and the narrator's commentaries are very charming but there are so little of them in the game...

But otherwise - the game is good. A breathe of fresh air among all those conveyor made games. I'm not sure if I would be replaying it again or buying the second part, but the time I've spent in this game I definitely not regret spending.

Human: Fall Flat - Whimsical Physics Puzzles for Hilarious Creativity

Rating: ★★★★☆

Human: Fall Flat, released in 2016, invites players into a charming and surreal world of physics-based puzzles and goofy escapades. Developed by No Brakes Games, the game offers a unique blend of puzzle-solving, creativity, and lighthearted humor that results in an entertaining and often hilarious gameplay experience.

The central character, Bob, is a customizable and delightfully clumsy humanoid who stumbles and tumbles through a series of dreamlike levels. The game's physics-driven mechanics are intentionally wonky, leading to comical and unexpected interactions with the environment. This intentional quirkiness is at the heart of the game's charm and appeal.

Each level of Human: Fall Flat is a sandbox of possibilities, tasking players with navigating intricate puzzles and obstacles. The game encourages creative problem-solving, allowing players to manipulate objects, climb surfaces, and experiment with the environment in their quest to reach the exit. The open-ended nature of the puzzles means that there are often multiple solutions, fostering a sense of accomplishment and ingenuity.

The cooperative multiplayer mode enhances the enjoyment, allowing you to tackle the challenges with friends. The chaotic and collaborative nature of solving puzzles together often results in hilarious outcomes, from inadvertently launching each other into the air to trying to coordinate complex maneuvers.

Human: Fall Flat's visual design is simple yet endearing, with its charmingly minimalistic environments and quirky character animations. The dreamlike settings, from ice caves to industrial complexes, offer a visually diverse and captivating backdrop for the puzzling adventures.

The game's humor is derived from the absurdity of the physics interactions and the ragdoll-like movements of the characters. Watching Bob stumble, flop, and flail through the environment is a constant source of amusement, and the unpredictability of the physics can lead to genuinely laugh-out-loud moments.

Despite its strengths, Human: Fall Flat does have its limitations. The intentionally awkward controls and physics mechanics, while a defining feature of the game, can also lead to occasional frustration when precision is required. Additionally, the lack of a comprehensive narrative or progression system may limit its long-term appeal for some players.

In conclusion, Human: Fall Flat offers a delightful and entertaining blend of physics-based puzzles, creativity, and humor. Its charming visuals, open-ended gameplay, and cooperative multiplayer mode make it a standout choice for players seeking a unique and lighthearted gaming experience.

If you're looking for a game that will tickle your funny bone and challenge your problem-solving skills in a whimsical and imaginative world, Human: Fall Flat is a delightful choice that promises laughter, creativity, and hours of engaging puzzle-solving fun.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

Human: Fall Flat is a unique puzzle game where the way to solve a puzzle isn't always clear, because the goal is to solve these puzzles however you would like. If you are new I recommend playing with friends, bonus points if on a voice call because it can be extremely funny when you see how athletic and wobbly these blob-shaped humans actually are.

When you play, try not to keep asking yourself if the way you solved it is the intended solution, because the intended solution is to have fun and maybe even find an interesting workaround on the way, although I do agree that sometimes the intended solution is the best way because it stretches out the time you play this game, which is good because this game is very fun.

Unless you speed-run, the game is kind of limited in the way that when you finish, the puzzles aren't as fun the second time when you already know how to solve them. Thankfully this is not that big of a problem though, because there is a lot of gameplay. When searching up the gameplay of Human: Fall Flat it says it takes 6 hours to complete, if focusing on the main objectives, and while I think that while this would be possible for a small group of new players to complete the main game this fast, it frankly would be a lot funner and easier to not rush through the dreams and to have a lot of fun. After the main dreams there are a bunch of 'extra' dreams, which usually have great themes (think 'City' or the new 'Miniature') and are sometimes bigger and/or better than the main levels. If I had to guess the average length of each dream for a new player, I would guess an average length of 2.5 (maybe 3?) hours. You could argue that some dreams take a lot shorter than that to complete, like the first level of the game, 'Mansion', which takes a new player around 5 minutes to complete, but those would cancel out with levels like 'Dark', that take closer to 4 hours for new players to complete. My estimate for the gameplay of Human: Fall Flat is 55-70 hours of gameplay (a good amount)

If you want to get a better idea of what Human: Fall Flat is like, definitely search up some play-throughs on youtube. I recommend Markiplier's play-through because even though he and his friends didn't finish it, it shows a very accurate way that new players play new levels and is also just very entertaining to watch..

For new players, the biggest tip I can give you is in movement: If you jump going diagonal (forward and left/right) you can jump a lot further than when jumping straight forward, and a run-up is more useful than you think. Also instead of wobbling around, if you hold forward and jump, and alternate every few jumps between left and right, you can go pretty fast and jump pretty far. After only a few jumps you go fast enough forward that you don't deviate that much left or right and it's not as hard to control as it sounds. Make sure that when running like this you have both arms pointed out to stabilise yourself. (not sure if this works when using a controller because I use keyboard/mouse but it should.)

The controls on keyboard/mouse are really easy to understand (just forward, backward, left, right, jump, for the keyboard and right hand, left hand, aim hands for mouse) but I have also heard that the controls are nice on controller and some people even recommend using controller first starting (I don't think it matters).

100/100 This game is definitely worth 10 bucks (maybe the price changed but that is how much I bought it for) but even if it was 40 bucks, I would still get it because it's very worth it. (I don't commonly spend money on games)

Human: Fall Flat is an absolute gem of a game that manages to blend comedy, physics, and puzzle-solving into an incredibly enjoyable experience. Developed by No Brakes Games, this title takes players on a journey through a whimsical and surreal world, where you control a clumsy and endearing character on a quest to overcome a series of unique challenges.

Right from the start, Human: Fall Flat captures your heart with its charming visuals and amusing character design. The intentionally awkward movements of your character are a constant source of laughter, making every step and jump a hilarious adventure. The game's cartoonish aesthetics perfectly complement the offbeat humor, creating an atmosphere of whimsy that keeps players engaged from start to finish.

What sets Human: Fall Flat apart from other puzzle games is its focus on unscripted problem-solving. Rather than presenting straightforward puzzles, the game encourages players to experiment and devise their own solutions. This freedom gives rise to a sense of accomplishment when you finally figure out an unconventional way to tackle an obstacle.

The physics-based gameplay adds an extra layer of enjoyment as you wrestle with objects and the environment to reach your objectives. The controls may seem unwieldy at first, but that's part of the charm – it's not about finesse but embracing the hilarity that comes with flopping around like a ragdoll.

The level design is another highlight of the game. Each dreamlike world presents a fresh set of challenges that cleverly test your ability to think outside the box. Whether you're scaling a daunting tower, navigating treacherous platforms, or manipulating contraptions, the variety and ingenuity of the puzzles keep you entertained throughout.

The multiplayer mode enhances the fun exponentially. Cooperating with friends to overcome obstacles often leads to uncontrollable laughter and memorable moments. Watching each other's characters stumble and fumble creates a shared experience that strengthens the bond between players.

On the downside, some players might find themselves occasionally frustrated by the lack of clear instructions. This can lead to moments of confusion or getting stuck in a level. However, it's important to remember that the game's open-ended nature is intentional and encourages players to embrace experimentation.

In conclusion, Human: Fall Flat is a delightful and refreshing addition to the puzzle-platformer genre. Its clever mix of physics-based challenges, charming visuals, and abundant humor make it an unforgettable experience. Whether playing solo or with friends, the game's ability to generate countless laughter-filled moments makes it a must-play for gamers seeking a lighthearted and engaging adventure. If you're ready to embark on an offbeat journey filled with hilarity and creativity, Human: Fall Flat is the perfect choice.

I've never played this game solo, nor do I intend to, but playing it with a friend or three is a very enjoyable experience.
It's pretty much a physics-based puzzle/platformer. Helping each other traverse the landscape and get past the puzzles.
There's room for a lot of co-operation and room for even more 'shenanigans', if that's your style of play.
The game can be tricky to get used to the controls, at least as far as newbies and casual gamers go, but if you've been gaming for years like I have, then it's pretty straight-forward.
I would even gladly have paid full-price for this game as there's a been a lot of new content, in the form of new maps, added since release for free, as updates.
When it's on sale, I'd say this is a Must-Buy.

Pros: Multiplayer can be occasionally silly; levels can be fun for players that like moderately difficult physics puzzles (or above moderately difficult easter egg achievements); level themes are varying; customizable avatars

Neutrals: Has physics that can range from pleasant to very frustrating (especially for the poorly designed player levels); online players can either be helpful or actively mess around, which mostly doesn't happen

Cons: Puzzle mechanics across some levels can feel repetitive; Their is no level or lobby builder tool; can't report players for inappropriate messages or avatar skins; can't block players from joining your lobby

Those faceless humanoids seemed so bland & clunky, but when you get the hang of it on joypad, dress them to your liking (you can draw/write stuff on the costumes in editor), give them names - kid's imagination transforms it all into a vast disneyland of activities. This game... baffles me. A physics-based puzzle-platformer designed to be janky and frustrating, yet I continue to play the levels and get mad over the puzzles. Is it just my innate sense to get all the achievements and consider it 'finished' in mine eyes? Or do I enjoy my way of cruising through levels by infini-climbing walls? Perhaps it is the possibilities of the character creator, or the anger caused by the very same character when their hand gets stuck behind their head, or internally losing my mind when I fail again and again to pick up and keep upright the small objects? I'm not sure what keeps me playing; and with a sequel coming out I will definitely see myself buying it; and I'm aware most people, once getting mad at the game, would quit and go on with their lives. But this game has its grip on me in some shape or form. Human: Fall Flat sure got me.

Human: Fall Flat is an absolute riot of fun, combining physics-based hilarity with open-ended creativity. The game's charmingly awkward protagonist stumbles and flops through surreal environments, turning every mundane task into a slapstick adventure.

The open-world design allows for endless possibilities, encouraging players to experiment with solving puzzles and completing challenges in their own zany ways. The multiplayer aspect amplifies the chaos, turning cooperative tasks into a symphony of laughter and collaboration.

The physics engine, while intentionally clumsy, adds an unpredictable and comical element to every action. Maneuvering your character may seem challenging at first, but it quickly becomes part of the charm, leading to unexpected and hilarious outcomes.

The game's minimalist aesthetic complements its whimsical nature, and the soothing background music enhances the overall laid-back atmosphere. The level design is ingenious, presenting players with puzzles that require both thought and experimentation.

Human: Fall Flat is a testament to the idea that gaming should be about joy and laughter. Its unique blend of physics-based antics and cooperative gameplay makes it a standout experience for friends looking to share a good laugh. Whether you're solving puzzles or tumbling through the world with friends, Human: Fall Flat is a delightful adventure in awkwardness that guarantees smiles and laughter throughout.
